titleStmt.title: Me, my brain and I: a framework for neuroscience curriculum fostering research-practice partnership between scientists and educators

analytic.title: Me, my brain and I: a framework for neuroscience curriculum fostering research-practice partnership between scientists and educators

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Students' school requirements and learning activities engage many different cognitive processes, including as language processing, memory, learning, attention, reasoning, decision making, and social interaction. However, student rarely learn about these cognitive processes or the brain mechanisms underlying them, and therefore lack critical understanding about they themselves operate. Here, we describe a novel neuroscience curriculum, developed through a Research-Practice Partnership (RPP) between neuroscientists and educators, aimed at providing students with the opportunity to learn about their own brain and cognitive abilities and engage in authentic neuroscientific inquiry. The curriculum is organized around three pillars: Learn Neuroscience-Experience Neuroscience-Contribute to Neuroscience. These are designed to optimize relevance, student engagement and interactive hands-on experience. In particular, by incorporating genuine neuroscientific research as part of the program, students are offered a front row seat to the scientific process using cuttingedge neurotechnology and gain first-hand experience with the challenges and excitements of scientific inquiry.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Making science education relevant to students' day-to-day experiences has become a central theme in education reform (e.g., Next General Science Standards (NGSS Lead States, 2013). Student-centered curricula that emphasize relevance lead to better learning outcomes, increase motivation, and foster more positive attitudes and interests in science (Ashwin, 2020;Baram-Tsabari & Yarden, 2009;Bedford, 2017;Chandrasena, Craven, Tracey, & Dillon, 2013;Jenkins & Nelson, 2005;Johnson, 2019;Slovinsky et al., 2021). A domain of science that holds particularly high relevance is Neuroscience since understanding the human brain is a topic that fascinates students and teachers alike (Chudler, 2010). Integrating neuroscience curriculum into science lessons offers an opportunity to spark students' curiosity and engage them in exploration of the mechanisms underlying their own behavior -their ability to learn, reason, feel, and interact with their peers (Gage, 2019;Tuttle & Davidesco, 2023).

Recent years have seen a rise in neuroeducation initiatives, which include teaching students about the brain and inviting them to think like neuroscientists (Ansari, Daniel & Coch, Donna, 2011;Azeka et al., 2020;Davidesco et al., 2021;Gosavi & Toomarian, 2024;Janssen & van Atteveldt, 2022;Thomas et al., 2019;Tuttle & Davidesco, 2023). Students who participate in neuroscience programs have shown increased growth mindsets, higher self-efficacy, increased critical thinking, and greater enthusiasm toward science (Ashwin, 2020;Gosavi & Toomarian, 2024;Howard-Jones et al., 2016;Howard-Jones, Paul, 2014;Kannan et al., 2024). These initiatives often emerge as research-practice partnerships (RPP), a fruitful framework that brings together researchers and educators (Coburn & Stein, 2010;Farrell et al., 2022). While many current neuroeducation programs are highly interactive, some of them lack a key element that is inherent to 'real' scientific inquiry: The excitement of investigating and learning something entirely new that has not been discovered before. Here, we describe a new RPP-based neuroscience curriculum that provides students the opportunity not only to learn about their brains but also to be part of advancing the field and engaging in genuine neuroscientific research.

div.head: The Teams: A Research-Practice Partnership (RPP) between Neuroscientists and Educators
div.p: This curriculum is the product of an RPP between neuroscientists at [anonymized; as per journal request] University (academic team) and educators from the [anonymized; as per journal request] high-school (educational team), both located in the city of [anonymized; as per journal request]. The academic team consisted of the PI, a postdoc, and several graduate and undergraduate students. The educational team consisted of the school principal and two science teachers.

div.head: Goals and Guiding Principles
div.p: Inspired by other lab-to-school programs, the academic and educational teams engaged in mutual goal-setting and alignment of expectations (Aldemir et al., 2022;da Silva Soares et al., 2021;Davidesco, et al., 2021;Gola et al., 2022;Landi et al., 2022).

Educational goals, curriculum details, and operational constraints were discussed jointly, to optimize program planning and its execution. The goals and guiding principles for this program, defined through this process, are as follows ( Figure 1): I) Learn science from real scientists: Students usually learn science from textbooks and from teachers who are not scientists themselves, which can make the scientific process seem somewhat foreign and removed. By bringing currently active neuroscientists to school to lead learning activities and interact with students, students are exposed not only to state-of-the-art scientific information but also to the 'behind the scenes' of the scientific process and scientists' personal stories. Studies have shown that direct engagement with scientists can enhance student performance and motivation, narrow the achievement gap for underrepresented students, and make academic careers more accessible through direct access to role models (Abramowitz et al., 2024;Aranda et al., 2021;Metzger et al., 2023;Theobald et al., 2020).

div.head: II) Relevance -me and my brain:
div.p: One of the captivating aspects of neuroscience is its relevance to everyone. Teenagers are particularly fascinated by the desire to understand their brain and 'what makes them tick'. Given the documented benefits of teaching science in a personally relevant manner (Stuckey et al., 2013), neuroscience seems like a natural choice. The curriculum described here focuses on aspects of neuroscience that 4 have direct relevance for high-school students, focusing on topics such as learning and memory, attention, emotions, social interaction, sports, and sleep.

div.head: III) Students as scientists:
div.p: Our program places a strong emphasis on active learning, hands-on activities, and open-ended inquiry. These approaches have been shown to spark high levels of interest in students and improve higher-level thinking skills such as comprehension, analysis, and application of knowledge across contexts (Azeka et al., 2020;Burke et al., 2020;Gosavi & Toomarian, 2024;Johnson, 2019;Julià & Antolí, 2019;Saido et al., 2018;Theobald et al., 2020).

div.head: Three-Pillars: Learn-Experience-Contribute
div.p: Guided by the goals and principles delineated above, we designed a neuroscience curriculum around three conceptual pillars: Learn Neuroscience -Experience Neuroscience -Contribute to Neuroscience (Figure 2). These pillars are translated into three learning modules. Below, we provide a general description of the goals included in each module. Then, in section 3, we provide a more detailed description of specific learning topics, materials, and approaches used in our RPP, and highlight points of consideration when designing similar curricula.

Module 1 -Learn Neuroscience: This is a relatively 'traditional' educational module aimed at introducing students to key concepts and basic facts of neuroscience. Lectures and group activities are taught by members of the academic team, to foster their direct connection and relationship with the students. We emphasize selecting topics that are highly relevant to students' lives and incorporating live demonstrations and active learning techniques in the lesson plan. The specific content and format of learning activities in this module can be tailored according to the preferences and goals of the educational team, and there is an abundance of readily available educational material that can be used (e.g., Backyard-brains: https://backyardbrains.com/experiments/; BrainFacts: https://www.brainfacts.org; Brainwaves: https://wp.nyu.edu/brainwaves/).

div.head: Example Curricula -Attention in the Brain
div.p: After laying out the modules of our neuroscience curriculum, which stem from the three conceptual pillars Learn-Experience-Contribute, we now turn to describe specific topics, learning materials, and educational approaches that we have used as part of our RPP.
We offer this as a prototype that can be adopted and adapted by other groups, to advance their own science education and research initiatives.

div.head: Specific Topic: "The Neuroscience of Attention"
div.p: We chose to focus our neuroscience curriculum on a specific topic: The Neuroscience of Attention. This topic was selected for several reasons. First, the research team has substantial expertise in the domain of attention (Makov et al. 2022; Har-shai Yahav & Zion Golumbic 2021; Kaufmann & Zion Golumbic 2022). This allowed us to capitalize on our broad scientific knowledge when creating learning materials and afforded a more personal perspective on the topic of scientific inquiry. Second, attention is one of the most important cognitive faculties that students need to use at school and one that frequently presents challenges to learners (Brand et al., 2002;Daley & Birchwood, 2010;Posner & Rothbart, 2014). Every day, almost all day long, students need to focus their attention on a teacher or on specific learning activities and suppress distraction from 7 both external sources (e.g., sounds from adjacent classrooms, other students chattering) and internal processes (e.g. boredom, mind-wandering, competing interests) (Arnold et al., 2020;Daley & Birchwood, 2010;Núñez-Jaramillo et al., 2021). The high relevance of attention to students and teachers makes it a perfect topic for an in-school neuroscience curriculum.
The third reason for selecting this topic is its high potential for real scientific contribution.

Despite extensive scientific and clinical research in the domain of attention, much is still lacking in our understanding of how attention operates in real-life contexts, particularly at school (Kim et al., 2020;Núñez-Jaramillo et al., 2021). Given the fundamental importance and the negative outcomes that distractibility during learning has on students with and without attentional deficits (Arnold et al., 2020;Daley & Birchwood, 2010), there is much to be gained from collaborating with students and teachers on designing attention-related studies and by carrying out this type of research within an organic school context.

In summary, we chose to focus on a topic for which the academic team has a high level of expertise, the students and teachers have a high level of interest, and that holds the potential for significant scientific contribution from conducting research in a school setting.

div.head: Module 1: Learn Neuroscience
div.p: This module served as the introductory stage for establishing a personal connection between the students and the research team, piquing students' curiosity about their own Barry et al., 2007), the difference between signals in different locations, and the effect of muscular artifacts (Muthukumaraswamy, 2013).

div.head: Module 2: Experience Neuroscience
div.p: In this hands-on module, students experience the scientific process from start to finish, both as participants and as researchers.

div.head: Examples of Lessons/activities:
div.p: à How can we measure attention? A key question in scientific research, and in neuroscience in particular, is how to operationalize the constructs of interest for empirical investigation. We introduce students to the process of operationalization by presenting several well-validated experimental paradigms used in attention research. Prominent examples include The Eriksen-Flanker paradigm (Eriksen & Eriksen, 1974;Stoffels & van der Molen, 1988), the Stroop paradigm (Stroop, 1935) and the Continuous Performance Tasks (Rosvold et al., 1956). Students work in small groups to discuss which aspects of attention can be reliably quantified using these paradigms, develop testable hypotheses, and discuss the pros and cons of different paradigms.
à Test my attention.

After being introduced to key paradigms in attention research, students partake in online versions of these tasks. Performing the experiment on yourself, rather than simply learning about it, raises new insights about the practical aspects of scientific research, including discussion of specific operational choices, potential confounding factors, and the relationship between the subjective experience of performing the task and the objective results.
à Work with real data. Data collected in class is used for a mini data-analysis project.

Students learn basic data-analysis skills such as averaging data, comparing conditions, and aggregating data across individuals. Since data are collected on highly validated tasks, class-based results can be compared to existing literature, prompting discussions about replication and scientific validity. In addition, working with real data prompts a better understanding of variance and individual differences.

à Let's talk science -students conference: An exciting and important aspect of science is its communication to different audiences. This requires one to fully understand the details of the study, to design visualization and a narrative that effectively conveys its significance, and to be able to answer questions and engage in fruitful discussions. We create this opportunity by convening a 'student conference' in which groups present their work to the class. Putting students in the position of 'experts' to present their scientific questions, hypotheses and results to peers is a powerful educational tool for increasing engagement in learning, generating enthusiasm and personal investment, developing communication skills and giving students a sense of achievement (Boud & Cohen, 2014).

div.head: Module 3: Contribute to Neuroscience
div.p: This module focuses on the thrill of making new discoveries. While in modules 1 & 2 students learn about science that has been done by others and replicate known effects, in module 3 they get to be part of a new experiment that has never been tested before.

Active involvement in research can take on different forms, from thinking about new experiments, being a participant in ongoing research or joining the research team. We offer students three paths for participation in research conducted within the school, pertaining to studying aspects of students' attention.

div.head: Paths to participating in attention research:
div.p: à Participate in an experiment: As part of our RPP, a classroom has been converted to an in-school neuroscience laboratory, where we conduct experiments with students using behavioral tasks, mobile EEG, and mobile eye-tracking devices. The specific experiments conducted in our in-school lab vary from semester to semester, however, the overall goal is to study different aspects of students' cognitive à Join the research team: Research in the in-school lab is led by graduate students from the University. However, students who choose to expand their neuroscience studies (10 th grade+), are offered the opportunity to join the team as research assistants (student RAs). This involves training on the various equipment in the lab, including applying the mobile EEG cap and measuring neural signals, as well as help in recruiting participants for the experiment and assistance during data collection.

Being an organic part of the research team is a rare opportunity for high-school students that can be immensely empowering and inspiring. Moreover, these students bring unique insights into the design of the research itself and play an important role in communicating the value of neuroscience research to their peers. Student RAs receive class credit for their participation in the research team and submit a scientific report about the research, which becomes part of their final matriculation grade. Students reported being motivated by knowing that they were part of a "real" scientific experiment and that they liked the interactive nature of the classes, which was different from their usual mode of learning. Several students also mentioned being proud to be part of this class and that they were excited to share knowledge they gained with their families and friends.

"The sessions with the research team from the university were fantastic. We explored scientific papers with them, which helped us design our own study. On the choice to focus on Neuroscience as a core element of the science curriculum, the educational team note that the relevance of this field to students' lives provides them with exciting opportunities to understand their own experiences better.

"When a child learns something in class but then can't retrieve it [e.g. on a test], this can be discouraging and might cause them to give up. But when someone explains how memory works, and why we sometimes forget things, then … understanding 'why' is already halfway to the solution". (teacher)
They also state that combining authentic research as part of the curriculum and establishing an in-school neuroscience lab, provides students with a unique and almost unprecedented opportunity.
"It arouses pride in them to say "I'm part of a real research". Being part of this generates self-competence, self-awareness and a sense of importance". (principal)

div.head: Research-team feedback
div.p: "There is an exciting sense of innovation that makes this work especially rewarding."
Interacting with students and teachers is not a common experience for those pursuing an academic career in neuroscience. Moreover, the skill set required for scientific research

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In recent years, there has been a surge in RPPs aiming to bridge neuroscience and education, disseminating scientific knowledge beyond university boundaries.

Initiatives in this have shown the significant benefits this holds for students, including increased engagement with science, knowledge acquisition, and enhanced feelings of success and self-efficacy (Azeka et al., 2020;Burke et al., 2020;Gosavi & Toomarian, 2024;Johnson, 2019;Julià & Antolí, 2019;Theobald et al., 2020). Our program aligns with these partnerships by affording students the opportunity to engage with neuroscience both as participants and as scientists and to form meaningful relationships with neuroscientists. What sets our program apart is its emphasis on choosing topics that are particularly relevant to students' lives, and inviting them into the scientific process itself. Furthermore, by exposing students to the natural neurodiversity within their own school and communities, they gain insights for addressing stigmas and normalizing preconceptions associated with various neuropsychological conditions and learning differences (Alipanopoulos et al., 2020;Sadow et al., 2002).

Discussing aspects of cognition and neural processing with students and educators not only contributes to their own understanding but can also provide the basis for advancing neuroscientific research itself. In recent years, there has been growing dissatisfaction with the limited ability of lab-based tests to reliably predict real-life performance, particularly in the domains of attention and learning. The disparity between lab-based metrics and real-life behavior stems from several factors, including the fact that lab-based tasks are removed from the type of tasks performed in real life (Faraone et al., 2021). Moreover, samples in lab-based studies are not sufficiently diverse and therefore may not be representative of the broader population (Falk et al., 2013;Hyde et al., 2020). Collaborating with schools on neuroscience research provides an exceptional opportunity to study behavioral and neural aspects of critical cognitive functions, in the organic environments where they are needed the most, in a diverse community-based sample (Wilcox et al., 2021). Based on our experience, we believe that building strong partnerships between academics and educators holds a symbiotic advantage, in which both sides have much to gain, advancing both science education and the science underlying education and learning.

div.head: Challenges and Opportunities
div.p: The unique opportunities of RPPs are not devoid of challenges. Here we describe some challenges we encountered along the way and insights that may assist others seeking to establish similar programs. Logistical Challenges: As opposed to lab-based work where we can control most elements, the RPP required us to adapt our practices to school constraints. Specific challenges included adapting our schedule to school timetables (e.g, inflexible class time, early-morning classes, fixed dismissal time, and frequent changes), the lack of control over class location and environmental factors (e.g., teaching a class or running experiments in a classroom adjacent to the basketball court), and the dynamics of student-life (e.g., behavioral issues, student tardiness, interruptions, social dynamics, and non-participation). Learning to work within the school framework required flexibility, adaptability, creativity, and (as noted above) good working relationships. In our case, the close geographical proximity between the university and high-school (approximately 2 miles) was helpful, as it afforded more flexibility to come and go between institutions as needed.

Integration of Mobile EEG Technology in Schools: Incorporating mobile EEG technology into the neuroscience curriculum represents a significant opportunity to enhance the learning experience (Faraone et al., 2021), and offers valuable insights into brain function and neuroscience principles. However, this integration requires substantial expertise and technological resources, as well as careful planning and coordination. This includes availability of appropriate EEG devices and supporting technology, knowledge of how to set them up quickly, and the ability to troubleshoot problems in real-time. That said, there are several ways that mobile EEG can be integrated as a teaching tool within the class, that vary in the technical savviness needed.

The simplest approach is to use mobile EEG for demonstration purposes only (similar to the example given above in Module 1). This does not require a very sophisticated EEG system, and many commercially available systems, that are based on dry or semi-dry electrodes can be adequate. The main challenge of conducting a live demonstration is minimizing the time it takes to show a clean signal and projecting it onto the screen for the class to observe. We recommend practicing setting up the EEG cap prior to the class and working in pairs, so that one person can deal with technical issues while the other explains what is happening. In our demonstrations, we used a 14-channel EMOTIV EPOC+ system, which our expert team was able to set up in ~5 minutes.

A more advanced approach is to give students hands-on experience with EEG to record data themselves (Gosavi & Toomarian, 2024;Tuttle & Davidesco, 2023) or learn something about their own neural responses (Davidesco, et al., 2021;Janssen & van Atteveldt, 2022). This approach requires a larger professional team working in small groups to guide several children at the same time, as well as several mobile EEG systems, laptops, and related equipment. More ambitious still is the concept of an in-school EEG lab, which serves a scientific purpose alongside its educational advantages. For this, offthe-shelf EEG systems might not suffice and a more elaborate research-grade system might be needed, with a larger number of electrodes and better signal quality (Niso et al., 2023). Moreover, collecting quality EEG requires a lengthier setup time, and additional peripheral equipment (e.g., means to synchronize between an experiment and the EEG signal) and should be conducted in a dedicated space. Therefore, many initiatives for collecting in-school EEG do so outside the regular class context, in a dedicated lab space, or in small learning groups (Davidesco et al., 2023;Ko et al., 2017;Poulsen et al., 2017;Wang et al., 2023;Xu et al., 2022).

div.head: Summary
div.p: The RPP-based neuroscience curriculum described here equips children with tools and knowledge from the field of neuroscience, offering them a new set of academic and practical skills (Gosavi and Toomarian, 2024) and empowering them to initiate, lead, and think critically about the science of what makes us who we are. While the current paper outlines one specific collaborative effort, we believe in the potential of RPPs to fundamentally change our approach to science education as well as the way scientific research about education and cognition is conducted. Specifically, the conceptual pillars delineated here can be expanded and applied in a variety of ways to develop longterm educational programs that provide children with a deeper understanding of themselves and the brain. Moreover, integrating an RPP approach with citizen science methodologies (Bopardikar et al., 2023;Kali et al., 2023;Roche et al., 2020) harbors the potential to substantially advance neuroscientific research of cognitive processes and their ecological relevance, as it would allow data collection on a scale typically unattainable in controlled academic research settings and would tap into diverse and extensive populations, studying cognitive and neural function in their real-life environments.

figure.head: Figure 1 :
figure.figDesc: The guiding principles informing the current RPP-based neuroscience curriculum.

figure.head: Module 2 -
figure.figDesc: Experience Neuroscience: In this module, students experience the scientific process hands-on, by conducting a mini-science project. For this, we use wellestablished paradigms in cognitive psychology, that are a) easy to implement on a webbased platform; b) are relatively short (~10 minutes) and c) are expected to produce robust results even in small samples (see section 3 for specific details). Students are introduced to the basic experimental design and the underlying research questions, then proceed to participate in the experiments themselves, and work in groups to formulate hypotheses regarding the results. Finally, they analyze and discuss the collected data about their hypotheses, and share their findings. This module provides students with the opportunity to think like researchers, work with real data collected in their classroom, and connect their findings to the existing research literature.Module 3 -Contribute to Neuroscience: While learning about and replicating wellestablished experiments can be a useful learning experience (Modules 1&2), the real excitement of science lies in the potential to make new discoveries. In Module 3 students are invited to partake in ongoing neuroscience research, transforming them from passive observers to active contributors, and giving them a 'first-row seat' to the intricacies of scientific research. Lessons in this module are devoted to designing new experiments together with the scientists, inviting students to develop new research questions, translating them into feasible experiments, reviewing the relevant literature, and developing hypotheses. Several modes of direct engagement are offered, including participating in ongoing experiments at the university lab or the in-school neuroscience lab (parental consent required) or joining the research team in the in-school neuroscience lab. Being part of ongoing neuroscientific research exposes students to the endless possibilities of scientific inquiry, but also to the realistic challenges and constraints as well as the need for methodological rigor in science work.

figure.head: Figure 2 :
figure.figDesc: The three conceptual pillars Learn-Experience-Contribute of the RPP neuroscience curriculum, the goals they aim to achieve and examples of lessons and learning activities for each pillar.

brains and exposing them to basic concepts and theories related to attention and the brain. Modes of teaching included short lectures, in-class demonstrations, and discussions of recent neuroscience research on attention and distractibility in the adolescent brain.Examples of Lessons:à A career in science: One of our primary goals was to foster a direct relationship with scientists, establish conversations about the importance of science to society and science as a career choice. As part of this module members of the research team share their personal journey to neuroscience, describe the focus of their research, and the opportunities and challenges in their work.à What do I want to know about my brain? To connect students more directly to the topic of inquiry, we engage in a discussion about the questions they have about their brain in general, and about attention specifically. à Attention in the Brain -how does it work? The theoretical portion of the module includes short lectures introducing basic terms about neural function and theories about how attention operates in the brain. We focus on different aspects of attention -e.g., selective attention, divided attention, sustained attention, and executive functions -and introduce the neural circuitry and function underlying them. à Neurodiversity in Attention: An important element in neuroscience, and attention in particular, is variability among people. To demonstrate the concept of neurodiversity,and to connect the topic to students' organic classroom experience we perform an (anonymous) online survey among students asking about the level of their attention "right now". Results are then presented to the class and discussed, emphasizing the idea that attention varies both between and within individuals.

Using commonly used paradigms in attention research, students develop hypotheses about experiment outcomes, collect and analyze data on well-validated paradigms, and engage in active discussions about the results and their application in small groups and through peer-to-peer teaching. This module connects theoretical concepts introduced in Module 1 to the process of empirical investigation.

performance and attention in an ecologically valid learning setting. Students enrolled in the Neuroscience curriculum are invited to participate in these experiments (contingent on providing written parental consent) and contribute to the scientific endeavor. Experiencing an authentic scientific experimental setup, and observing one's own neural activity and other signals measured within the context of a regular school environment, is an extremely thought-provoking and exciting opportunity for students. They have a first-row seat to the technology, scientific approach, and challenges of conducting field research in neuroscience. After the experiment, the research team collects feedback from participants and engages in a discussion of the research goals and real-life relevance of this study, furthering students' opportunity to learn about the process of science up close and contribute their insights.

figure.head: à
figure.figDesc: Design your own experiment: Another path for engagement in the advancement of science is by suggesting new ideas for research. As part of the neuroscience curriculum, students are asked to think of a novel research question pertaining to attention at school. Over the course of several weeks, they design a way to test this question using the available tools (online surveys and simple behavioral tasks), recruit participants from the school for their experiment, collect data, analyze it and ultimately present it to the class in poster form. Examples of attention-related questions studied by students in our program include the assessment of student distractibility at different times of the day, difference between attention during schooldays vs. the weekend, and differences in self-assessments of attention in students with and without a diagnosis of ADHD. Developing new ideas for researchwhich stem from students' real-life school experiences and genuine interest, and providing them with the tools and guidance for carrying them out, is perhaps the ultimate fulfillment of the notion of "relevance" in science education. Being part of this endeavor will undoubtedly leave a lasting impression in shaping these students' understanding of themselves and of the scientific process.

and acquired during graduate school) does not necessarily equip scientists to work with high-schoolers. Although many on the research team had informal experience working with children and adolescents, none had a formal background in education. At first, this was challenging and required adapting teaching methods, expectations, and attitudes toward the students. However, as relationships developed and the program solidified, the research team became more comfortable in classroom settings and the mutual benefits and learning potential became apparent: "The first meeting was exciting and stressful. I have worked with children before but this was very different from meeting children who come for an experiment. But as time passed, I felt that a real connection had been formed with the students that allowed us to have an open conversation on a variety of topics" "Their genuine interest and willingness to share their thoughts created a dynamic learning environment. This strong connection has been incredibly meaningful for both sides." Since our RPP focused on "the Neuroscience of Attention" which is the primary expertise of the research team, the interaction with students afforded a unique scientific perspective on this topic. Most notable perhaps is the ecological relevance and aspects of neurodiversity that can be addressed when studying attention in a school lab. The research team noted this impacted their own scientific thinking and sparked new ideas. "Witnessing their curiosity firsthand has undoubtedly impacted my own research. Their questions and perspectives have guided me towards more relevant research questions". "Beyond the excitement of working with the children, this research introduced me to new ways of connecting neuroscience and education.

Building and Nurturing Partnership: RPP success hinges on the strength of the relationships forged between the research team and the educational staff. Specifically, both sides must be equally invested in the partnership's goals and outcomes. As such, fostering open communication, trust, and shared vision is essential for sustaining productive collaborations over time. While the dynamics of each partnership may vary, the underlying principle of mutual respect and cooperation remains universal.

One of the most exciting elements in our neuroscience curriculum is a live demonstration of students' brain waves. For this purpose, we use a mobile EEG system (EMOTIV EPOC+) that can be easily setup in class. The EEG system is a student volunteer (many students are typically excited for this opportunity) and their brainwaves are projected for the entire class to see. This typically produces a 'wow moment' for all students, who are stimulated and inspiredby the prospect of 'looking into the brain'. The research team demonstrates specific features of the EEG signal, including alpha-waves (eyes-open vs. eyes-closed comparison;

figure.figDesc: Student feedback to participating in the neuroscience curriculum was overwhelmingly positive. Students noted that being part of this program not only taught them a lot about the topic of attention and the field of neuroscience in general but, helped them develop
